p: Ensure all public interfaces used for testing your application are removed.
Test interfaces add extra functionality that will be used by a test team to gain information or drive functionalityÂ but would be dangerous in the hands of an attacker.

Identify all test interfaces. Examine your application's code base and identify any public interfaces that are not documented in your application's API specifications. If you use derived classes or interfaces, make sure all the base classes/interfaces are also reviewed. For example:

Ensure all test interface are removed. Ensure all public test APIs are removed from the base classes/interfaces. If you cannot modify the source code of the base classes/interfaces, ensure that all derived classes are declared final and contain a no-op method to overwrite the original test API:

Identify all test APIs: Enumerate all public APIs. Identify which APIs are intended for application use and which APIs are intended for test purposes. Ideally these interfaces will already be documentedÂ properly and can be discovered through specifications.
Remove the test interfaces: Code removal is a straight forward procedure. Once the test code is identified, it should be isolated from the application and removed from your code base.

The following code shows the user management system for an application. Because the class contains test APIs, it is possible for a malicious user to execute untested code and possibly exploit any vulnerabilities in it.
The following code shows the user management system for an application. Because the test API is removed from the class, there is no untested code that a malicious user can attack.

Identify all test interfaces. Examine your application's code base and identify any public interfaces that are not documented in your application's API specifications. If you use derived classes or interfaces, make sure all the base classes/interfaces are also reviewed. For example: 
      public class UserManager{    ...    // A test method to remove all accounts    public boolean removeAllAccounts()    {       ...    }    ...}public class MyAppUserManager extends UserManager{    // An attacker who has access to this interface    // automatically gain access to removeAllAccounts()}

Ensure all test interface are removed. Ensure all public test APIs are removed from the base classes/interfaces. If you cannot modify the source code of the base classes/interfaces, ensure that all derived classes are declared final and contain a no-op method to overwrite the original test API:
        public class UserManager{Â Â Â  ...Â Â Â Â // A test method to remove all accountsÂ Â Â  public boolean removeAllAccounts()Â Â Â  {Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  ...Â Â Â  }Â Â Â  ...}public final class MyAppUserManager extends UserManager{Â Â   // Making the method no-op will prevent an attacker from calling the removeAllAccounts() method.Â Â Â  final public boolean removeAllAccounts()    {        return false;    }}

Identify all test APIs: Enumerate all public APIs. Identify which APIs are intended for application use and which APIs are intended for test purposes. Ideally these interfaces will already be documentedÂ properly and can be discovered through specifications.
Remove the test interfaces: Code removal is a straight forward procedure. Once the test code is identified, it should be isolated from the application and removed from your code base.

public final class UserManager{      public UserManager()      {            ...      }      public boolean addUser(User user, char[] pass, char[] verifyPass)      {            ...      }      public boolean removeUser(User user)      {            ...      }      public boolean modifyUser(User user)      {            ...      }      public boolean changePass(User user, char[] oldPass,                                char[] pass, char[] verifyPass)      {            ...      }      // The class contains test APIs      public void addTestUsers()      {            ...      }}

// The class contains no test APIspublic final class UserManager{      public UserManager()      {            ...      }      public boolean addUser(User user, char[] pass, char[] verifyPass)      {            ...      }      public boolean removeUser(User user)      {            ...      }      public boolean modifyUser(User user)      {            ...      }      public boolean changePass(User user, char[] oldPass,                                char[] pass, char[] verifyPass)      {            ...      }}

html:
What to Check For

Ensure all public interfaces used for testing your application are removed.

Why

Test interfaces add extra functionality that will be used by a test team to gain information or drive functionality but would be dangerous in the hands of an attacker.

How to Check

  1. Identify all test interfaces. Examine your application's code base and identify any public interfaces that are not documented in your application's API specifications. If you use derived classes or interfaces, make sure all the base classes/interfaces are also reviewed. For example: 

    public class UserManager
    {
        ...
        // A test method to remove all accounts
        public boolean removeAllAccounts()
        {

           ...
        }
        ...
    }
    public class MyAppUserManager extends UserManager
    {
        // An attacker who has access to this interface
        // automatically gain access to removeAllAccounts()
    }

  2. Ensure all test interface are removed. Ensure all public test APIs are removed from the base classes/interfaces. If you cannot modify the source code of the base classes/interfaces, ensure that all derived classes are declared final and contain a no-op method to overwrite the original test API:

    public class UserManager
    {
        ...
        // A test method to remove all accounts
        public boolean removeAllAccounts()
        {
            ...
        }
        ...
    }

    public final class MyAppUserManager extends UserManager
    {
        // Making the method no-op will prevent an attacker from calling the removeAllAccounts() method.
        final public boolean removeAllAccounts()
        {
            return false;
        }
    }

How to Fix

To remove all test interfaces:

  1. Identify all test APIs: Enumerate all public APIs. Identify which APIs are intended for application use and which APIs are intended for test purposes. Ideally these interfaces will already be documented properly and can be discovered through specifications.

  2. Remove the test interfaces: Code removal is a straight forward procedure. Once the test code is identified, it should be isolated from the application and removed from your code base.

Problem Example

The following code shows the user management system for an application. Because the class contains test APIs, it is possible for a malicious user to execute untested code and possibly exploit any vulnerabilities in it.

public final class UserManager
{
      public UserManager()
      {
            ...
      }
      public boolean addUser(User user, char[] pass, char[] verifyPass)
      {
            ...
      }
      public boolean removeUser(User user)
      {
            ...
      }
      public boolean modifyUser(User user)
      {
            ...
      }
      public boolean changePass(User user, char[] oldPass,
                                char[] pass, char[] verifyPass)
      {
            ...
      }
      // The class contains test APIs
      public void addTestUsers()
      {
            ...
      }
}

Solution Example

The following code shows the user management system for an application. Because the test API is removed from the class, there is no untested code that a malicious user can attack.

// The class contains no test APIspublic final class UserManager
{
      public UserManager()
      {
            ...
      }
      public boolean addUser(User user, char[] pass, char[] verifyPass)
      {
            ...
      }
      public boolean removeUser(User user)
      {
            ...
      }
      public boolean modifyUser(User user)
      {
            ...
      }
      public boolean changePass(User user, char[] oldPass,
                                char[] pass, char[] verifyPass)
      {
            ...
      }
}

Java Deployment Guidelines

  • Remove Test Accounts
  • Remove Test Interfaces
  • Disable Directory Browsing
  • Use a Least-Privileged Account for Running Applications
  • Protect the JAAS Policy and Configuration Files
  • Protect Sensitive Data Inside Configuration Files

Java Deployment Checklists

  • Test Accounts Are Removed
  • Test Interfaces Are Removed
  • Directory Browsing Is Disabled
  • A Least Privileged Account Is Used for Running Applications
  • JAAS Policy and Configuration Files Are Protected
  • Sensitive Data Inside Configuration Files Is Protected
